quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of these themes is simple, pragmatic advice. Sell shit, make money.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A blunt reminder to prioritize revenue and real customer demand over abstract strategy or hype.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of my mantras is just don't die. Being coached and being reminded of the fundamentals and basics puts you in the right mindset.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A survival-first operating principle that emphasizes resilience and returning to fundamentals when things get hard.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Seems like an unsolved problem. You'll get all this positive feedback from the world and people have been starting that startup since the '90s.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A warning sign for “tarpit ideas”: problems that attract endless enthusiasm but repeatedly fail in practice over decades.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A good pivot is like going home. It's warmer, it's closer to something that you're an expert at.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for evaluating pivots: the best ones move you toward founder advantage and deeper competence.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There's a lot of founders that come this close to it, all being over and through sheer will just keep it going.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Highlights how persistence through near-failure moments is a common pattern among startups that ultimately succeed.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Eppo)
quotes.context: A clear, actionable principle that frames experimentation as a core growth and product-learning discipline.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Eppo)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology focus—move faster while maintaining analytical rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most was our experimentation platform where I could set up experiments easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Eppo)
quotes.context: A concrete example of an effective operating model: self-serve experimentation that reduces dependency and cycle time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta's market-leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance alongside reporting and tracking risks.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Vanta)
quotes.context: An actionable security/compliance approach: treat compliance as continuous monitoring plus risk tracking, not a one-time audit scramble.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Vanta)
quotes.context: A specific, practitioner-relevant efficiency claim tied to a common operational bottleneck (security questionnaires).

quotes.topic_title: Simple fundamentals: sell, make money, don’t die
quotes.text: And I think the reason this is true is that even if you're in the best in the world, being coached and being reminded of the fundamentals and basics is what puts you in the right mindset and that you already know everything, right?
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A mental model for why “obvious” advice still matters: elite performance comes from repeated reinforcement of fundamentals, not secret tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Simple fundamentals: sell, make money, don’t die
quotes.text: And so yeah, one of my mantras is just don't die. Just keep your startup going. Just keep going.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A simple operating principle founders can apply immediately: prioritize survival and continuity over perfection or flashy strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Simple fundamentals: sell, make money, don’t die
quotes.text: It's just the constant affirmation that continuing to keep going and doing high quality reps is the game.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A practical methodology: focus on consistent execution and iteration (“high quality reps”) as the core driver of startup progress.

quotes.topic_title: Simple fundamentals: sell, make money, don’t die
quotes.text: It's not that I said some Ninja 5D chess mood that they never would've thought of before.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that transformative startup advice is often unglamorous and non-novel—what matters is applying basics relentlessly.

quotes.topic_title: How not to die—and when to quit
quotes.text: The way to summarize that is if you look at all the startup stories that we have at YC and all the companies we funded over all the years, the underlying theme is that rationally the founder should have given up at some point.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A contrarian mental model: many breakout outcomes require persistence that looks irrational in the moment.

quotes.topic_title: How not to die—and when to quit
quotes.text: And so again, let's talk about Airbnb, obviously something you know a lot about. They probably should have shut down three or four times before they got into YC. It objectively wasn't working. They were basically ruining their lives, they were disappointing their parents, everything was wrong and it was a purely irrational act for the founders of Airbnb to keep working on their goofy startup.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A concrete example illustrating how “near-death” periods can precede eventual success.

quotes.topic_title: How not to die—and when to quit
quotes.text: One, are you still having fun? Do you still enjoy doing what you're doing? Do you enjoy spending time with your co-founders? Is this actually a fun thing you're doing? And if the answer there is yes, I would tend to lean on the keep going.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A practical decision filter for whether to persist: enjoyment of the work and team is a leading indicator to continue.

quotes.topic_title: How not to die—and when to quit
quotes.text: And then if it's more of, wow, this is actually profoundly affecting me a negative way and my relationships with people in my life and I don't really want to work with my co-founder anymore and things like that, then I would lean on the probably don't do it anymore.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A clear “quit” heuristic: when the startup is damaging your life and relationships, shutting down is often the right call.

quotes.topic_title: How not to die—and when to quit
quotes.text: We have such a short life. There's only so many years we get to have our careers, doing something that makes you miserable and the only reason you're doing it is to avoid losing face and you know in your heart is not going to work, I don't know, that seems like a pretty big opportunity cost on literally your life. Right?
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Reframes “not quitting” as a costly tradeoff—persisting purely to save face can waste years of your life.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone struggles: Brex and Retool turnaround story
quotes.text: And so if you just took this snapshot in time in the middle of the batch of who is definitely not doing well, it would clearly have been this Vyond company and this Cashew company.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Highlights how mid-journey comparisons can be misleading, cautioning founders against over-weighting temporary performance snapshots.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone struggles: Brex and Retool turnaround story
quotes.text: And so out of my 35 companies, the ones that objectively seemed the worst in terms of everything is going bad, were by far, in retrospect, the most successful companies in that group.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example showing that early “doom” signals can precede the biggest outcomes, reinforcing resilience and openness to change.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone struggles: Brex and Retool turnaround story
quotes.text: Usually a successful pivot gets warmer instead of colder from what you're an expert at and somehow builds on what you learned on the prior idea.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Provides a practical pivot heuristic: move closer to your expertise and reuse learnings rather than jumping to unrelated ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Everyone struggles: Brex and Retool turnaround story
quotes.text: You need to work more on the thing all about and not the thing nothing about.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb for choosing direction—lean into domains where you have real knowledge and advantage.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great pivot
quotes.text: Usually a successful pivot gets warmer instead of colder from what you're an expert at and somehow builds on what you learned on the prior idea.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A simple mental model for evaluating pivots: move closer to founder expertise and compound learnings rather than starting from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great pivot
quotes.text: A good pivot is like going home. It's warmer, it's closer to something that you... And it never occurred to you that this thing you know all about would be a good idea or maybe you consciously are like, "I don't want to work on this because burnt out on it." Sometimes someone has to get over this barrier they have on why they don't want to work on a certain idea.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive pivot pattern: the best idea may be in the domain you’re avoiding due to burnout or bias, and overcoming that resistance can unlock traction.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great pivot
quotes.text: And so there's no way those founders could have started with the final idea. You get what I mean?
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Reframes pivoting as a discovery process where the “right” idea often can’t be known upfront without prior iterations.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great pivot
quotes.text: There was no universe where they would've made up the idea for Segment because they didn't know anything about how analytics worked, but because they were grinding for multiple years and became experts on these things is a side effect of their earlier ideas. They ended up with really good unique insights.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A concrete example (Segment) showing how persistence on earlier attempts can manufacture domain expertise that enables a breakout pivot.

quotes.topic_title: When to pivot: ideas left in the tank
quotes.text: I would look at how many more ideas the founder has on how to make it grow.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic framework for deciding whether to persist or pivot based on remaining credible growth experiments.

quotes.topic_title: When to pivot: ideas left in the tank
quotes.text: If it's not going well and you're out of ideas, that is usually a good time to pivot.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Actionable pivot trigger: lack of progress plus no real next experiments suggests switching directions.

quotes.topic_title: When to pivot: ideas left in the tank
quotes.text: But when you have half a dozen or a dozen really good growth ideas that you haven't tried yet, try them. Right? Hey, give it a shot.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Encourages founders to exhaust a meaningful backlog of specific growth tests before pivoting.

quotes.topic_title: When to pivot: ideas left in the tank
quotes.text: Again, in the Airbnb story, right? They tried all sorts of stuff including cereal and conventions. They had a bunch of zany ideas on growth and they didn't run out of them.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that persistence can be rational when founders keep generating distinct, testable growth ideas.

quotes.topic_title: When to pivot: ideas left in the tank
quotes.text: And when literally the founder is like, "Yeah, I don't know, I guess maybe we should pay influencers or something." When that's the kind of ideas they're coming up with, that might be a better sign to pivot.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic: generic, grasping tactics can signal the idea is depleted and it’s time to pivot.

quotes.topic_title: Zip’s pivot process: hated incumbents in big markets
quotes.text: my suggestion was to start by looking at what companies are publicly traded and/or owned by private equity that are large and that also are hated by their customers, and to try to intentionally find where there's a knowable big market within incumbent combined with the software is horrible.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A concrete market-selection heuristic: target big, entrenched incumbents (public/PE-owned) that customers hate and whose software is bad.

quotes.topic_title: Zip’s pivot process: hated incumbents in big markets
quotes.text: And they did that. They basically found out about all this procurement software and what the state of the art was and that was the prompt.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Shows how the heuristic translated into a specific discovery process that led Zip into procurement software.

quotes.topic_title: Zip’s pivot process: hated incumbents in big markets
quotes.text: Basically find a large incumbent with very low NPS and try to disrupt them. So straightforward.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A crisp, practitioner-friendly rule of thumb for identifying disruption opportunities using NPS as a signal.

quotes.topic_title: Zip’s pivot process: hated incumbents in big markets
quotes.text: I can't promise that works for everyone, but again, in the very bespoke situation with Rujul, it worked really well because he actually knew exactly once he locked in on that prompt, oh man, he ran a masterclass.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A reminder that even strong frameworks are founder-context-dependent—and execution after choosing the prompt is decisive.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding copycat ideas: change your information diet
quotes.text: People all have the same idea. Basically imagine this, imagine your information consumption where you're listening to the same podcast, wink, wink, you're reading the same people on Twitter, you're reading the same blog post. Basically you have the same information diet of all these other founders and you're friends with all the same people. Does it seem surprising then that you would all end up with similar startup ideas or similar philosophies on what makes a good startup idea? Of course you are.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A clear causal model for why founders converge on copycat ideas: shared inputs (media + social graph) produce shared outputs (startup ideas).

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding copycat ideas: change your information diet
quotes.text: So this is the metaphor on cities is that if you just are following the same principles and have the same information flow into your brain, you're going to come up with the same ideas with everybody else.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A memorable mental model linking idea originality to diversifying the “information flow” you consume.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding copycat ideas: change your information diet
quotes.text: And so the prompt here is to try to go more off the beaten path either from your personal experience, like in the case of Brex and Retool or Whatnot. There was no one else trying to build marketplaces for Funko Pops. Go deeper in your own personal interests or experience to find something that just your exact peer wouldn't come up with in exactly the same way.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for generating differentiated ideas: mine personal experience and niche interests, illustrated with concrete startup examples.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding copycat ideas: change your information diet
quotes.text: A few years ago, startups around trucking were super new and fresh because no one was doing them and they worked really well and then it became completely conventional wisdom to do trucking related startups.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A pattern practitioners can watch for: once an “unfashionable” sector yields wins, it rapidly becomes crowded and conventional.

quotes.topic_title: Tarpit ideas: why some “great” ideas trap founders
quotes.text: By definition it is only a tarpit if it seems like it's not.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Defines the core mental model: tarpit ideas are dangerous precisely because they don’t look like bad ideas at first.

quotes.topic_title: Tarpit ideas: why some “great” ideas trap founders
quotes.text: The weird aspect of what we call a tarpit idea is an idea that a lot of people come up with and then it seems like an unsolved problem and you get lots of positive feedback for.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Highlights the key diagnostic signal: widespread founder convergence plus strong early enthusiasm can be a warning sign, not validation.

quotes.topic_title: Tarpit ideas: why some “great” ideas trap founders
quotes.text: Part of being a true tarpit is that you can get good initial validation.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: early validation can be misleading and is not sufficient evidence an idea is viable.

quotes.topic_title: Tarpit ideas: why some “great” ideas trap founders
quotes.text: If you ask your friends, "Hey, would you like an app for us to coordinate to hang out more so we can be friends?" They're like, "Yeah, I would love that." You'll get all this positive feedback from the world.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Concrete example of a tarpit pattern: ideas that sound universally desirable in conversation but repeatedly fail as startups.

quotes.topic_title: Tarpit ideas: why some “great” ideas trap founders
quotes.text: And then they never use it again.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Memorable illustration of the retention trap: users may react with excitement once, but the product doesn’t become a habit.

quotes.topic_title: Why investors say no and TAM at early stage
quotes.text: Maybe my best advice here is for founders to put themselves in the shoes of investors and just imagine what their life is like and how if you are in their shoes you would make decisions.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A practical mental model for interpreting investor behavior and tailoring your fundraising approach accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Why investors say no and TAM at early stage
quotes.text: And so there's lots of things that an investor that in their hearts thinks it is pretty good and they're like, "Oh, I like this person and I like their pitch, but I only am going to do a few investments. And so even though I really like a lot about this, I'm going to say no."
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Explains that many rejections are portfolio-constraint decisions, not necessarily a negative judgment on the founder or idea.

quotes.topic_title: Why investors say no and TAM at early stage
quotes.text: Or again, I know you do investments too, so it's that you only get so many shots as an investor. And so anything that doesn't seem like this is the one, this is the one I want to do is a no.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A crisp heuristic for why investors default to “no” unless a deal clearly clears a very high conviction bar.

quotes.topic_title: Why investors say no and TAM at early stage
quotes.text: I think it really depends on what stage you're investing at and it's absolutely critical the later stage you get. Right? If you're going to invest in a very high valuation, it is really important. The earlier you go, the less it matters.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A stage-based framework for when TAM should (and shouldn’t) dominate the investment decision.

quotes.topic_title: Why investors say no and TAM at early stage
quotes.text: TI funded Razorpay, which is I think the largest payment processor in India, and the TAM of that was tiny because no one was using credit cards in 2015 in India. So you had to believe that the size of the credit card industry in India would 100X. Well, guess what happened?
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how early TAM can look small when the real bet is market expansion over time.

quotes.topic_title: Product leadership: don’t overdelegate or overhire early
quotes.text: the advice that he's referencing here is just how important it is to not overdelegate and for the founders to stay close to things, as well as watch out for the trap of hiring super senior people with fancy resumes, really early in a startup.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A clear warning against early overdelegation and premature senior hiring that pulls founders away from the core work.

quotes.topic_title: Product leadership: don’t overdelegate or overhire early
quotes.text: you can't delegate caring about your users and you can't delegate caring that the product is great.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A memorable principle that product quality and user empathy must remain a founder-owned responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Product leadership: don’t overdelegate or overhire early
quotes.text: you get pushed often by investors to hire executives or to scale the team or you raise all this money, you got to spend it, you got to show you're serious about growth and building a world-class organization, whatever, stuff like that.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Highlights a common external pressure pattern that leads startups to scale org structure before product is solid.

quotes.topic_title: Product leadership: don’t overdelegate or overhire early
quotes.text: And then they hire them and then you wake up one day and you're like, "Oh wow, everything went wrong." It's not really anyone's fault, it's just that you took your eye off the ball and this is what happens to first-time founders a lot.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A cautionary story about how “great hires” can still produce failure when founders stop directly driving product.

quotes.topic_title: Product leadership: don’t overdelegate or overhire early
quotes.text: spending tons and tons of time hanging out with investors and networking, it's probably the thing that I would be cutting.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization advice: cut low-leverage activities to protect time for product and customers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's where I keep my content calendar, my guest research, and also the questions that I plan to ask each guest.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of using a single system to centralize planning inputs for repeatable execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Coda, you can stay aligned and ship faster by managing your planning cycles in one location.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an operational methodology: consolidate planning cycles to improve alignment and speed.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can set and measure OKRs with full visibility across teams and stakeholders.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on making goal-setting measurable and transparent to drive accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can map dependencies, create progress visualizations, and identify risk areas.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical checklist of planning tactics teams can apply to de-risk execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Head over to Coda.io/Lenny to sign up and get $1,000 in credit.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific, actionable offer that provides a tangible resource for startups to try the tool.

quotes.topic_title: Why startups fail: losing hope and founder conflict
quotes.text: I completely agree with what Gustav said, but to look at this from a different frame, I think is that the founders lose hope.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Reframes startup failure away from tactics (e.g., PMF) toward a psychological breaking point founders can actively manage.

quotes.topic_title: Why startups fail: losing hope and founder conflict
quotes.text: It doesn't always work, but it's almost like you have to not accept that you're going to fail. And as long as you don't accept that that's going to happen, there's usually a lot more moves you can try to save the company.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Actionable mindset: treat survival as a choice that unlocks additional strategic options (profitability, pivots, new launches).

quotes.topic_title: Why startups fail: losing hope and founder conflict
quotes.text: And so it's pretty rare, I would argue, that the cause of death is that they had lots of firepower and they were feeling really positive and they just ran out of money. That's actually more rare than founders think.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Contrarian observation that challenges the common fear that “running out of money” is the primary failure mode.

quotes.topic_title: Why startups fail: losing hope and founder conflict
quotes.text: And it's way more common that their idea doesn't work and they have a big fight with their co-founder, and then they can't agree on what to work on, and then they just like, "I don't want to do this anymore." And they shut down. That is the most common cause of death, is something that sounds like that story.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Highlights founder conflict + loss of conviction as a dominant failure pattern practitioners can proactively mitigate.

quotes.topic_title: Why startups fail: losing hope and founder conflict
quotes.text: I would argue that if we define it as the company had a near death experience where it was going poorly and the founders seriously wondered if it was all going to be over, a hundred percent of the time people go through that where the founder's like, "Yeah, I guess we're done. I guess we should pack it in."
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: Normalizes “near-death” moments as universal, helping founders persist through what feels like definitive failure.

quotes.topic_title: How to talk to customers: in-person reps and calendar time
quotes.text: And you can't just hide behind your keyboard and call that talking to customers. Right?
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that real customer discovery requires direct interaction, not just online proxies.

quotes.topic_title: How to talk to customers: in-person reps and calendar time
quotes.text: You can do a self-assessment. In the past month, how many in-person physical meetings have I had with potential customers?
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A concrete diagnostic question founders can use to measure whether they’re truly doing customer discovery.

quotes.topic_title: How to talk to customers: in-person reps and calendar time
quotes.text: I think it's look at your calendar and there should be 20 or 30% of your time that the calendar says something like customer meeting, customer call, meeting with who, meeting with this person.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A practical time-allocation heuristic for ensuring customer conversations are a real priority, not an aspiration.

quotes.topic_title: How to talk to customers: in-person reps and calendar time
quotes.text: And nothing substitutes for an actual conversation versus just staring at analytics dashboards.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A clear prioritization rule: qualitative conversations beat passive metrics for early learning.

quotes.topic_title: How to talk to customers: in-person reps and calendar time
quotes.text: The Collison Install is what often happens with customers, is that they say, "Yes, I want you buy your product." And then they do not implement it, they just go quiet.
quotes.speaker: Dalton Caldwell
quotes.context: A memorable pattern describing a common failure mode in B2B: verbal commitment without implementation leading to churn.
